neighbors.name: Jason Thornock & Tracy Thornock
neighbors.claims: Jason and Tracy Thornock are third-generation ranchers in the Cokeville area of Lincoln County, Wyoming [Inside Climate News](https://insideclimatenews.org/news/14122025/cokeville-wyoming-ranch-scale-solar/). They have actively pursued on-site renewable energy, including applying for an $868,000 federal grant to build a 648-kilowatt solar array and supporting state legislation to expand net metering for ranch-scale solar systems [Inside Climate News](https://insideclimatenews.org/news/16032025/wyoming-rooftop-solar-net-metering-energy-independence/) [WyoFile](https://wyofile.com/rancher-backed-solar-power-bill-loses-glimmer-with-amendments/). Jason Thornock testified to state lawmakers that Rocky Mountain Power’s actions nearly bankrupted his ranching business, and he later lost a court battle over those utility disputes which left him paying the company’s legal fees [Inside Climate News](https://insideclimatenews.org/news/14122025/cokeville-wyoming-ranch-scale-solar/) [Justia](https://law.justia.com/cases/wyoming/supreme-court/2016/s-15-0108.html).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage through a respected fellow rancher or trusted community leader. Emphasize how the project can help sustain their family ranch for future generations while allowing local input and control, aligning with their values of independence and legacy.
